item.title: Need some help with Math, in Java. Help is appreciated
item.dc:creator: @x1_att_ftw_x x1 att ftw x
item.description:
@x1_att_ftw_x wrote:

oh the math class?
math.abs(x)
absolute value, yes we learned that haha
This assignment is just a bonus, we didn’t learn how to approach something like this but if we manage to finish it then we got 2 bonus marks.

i have everything up to quarters working

[code=java]
public static int loonies, toonies, quarters, dimes, nickles, pennies;
public static double change = 1.86;
public static double change2;
public static void main(String[] args) {
toonies = (int) (change / 2);
loonies = (int) (change / 1);
change2 = change * 100 - 100;
quarters = (int) (change2 / 25);
//change2 = change2 * 10 - 25;
dimes = (int) (change2 / 10 % 10);
//change2 = change * 5 - 5;
nickles = (int) (change2 / 5 % 5);
//change2 = change * 1 - 1;
pennies = (int) (change2 / 1 % 1);
System.out.println();
System.out.println("Amount Of Change: " + change);
System.out.println(“Toonies:\t” + toonies);
System.out.println(“Loonies:\t” + loonies);
System.out.println(“Quarters:\t” + quarters);
System.out.println(“Dimes:\t\t” + dimes);
System.out.println(“Nickles:\t” + nickles);
System.out.println(“Pennies:\t” + pennies);
}

}[/code]

item.title: Need some help with Math, in Java. Help is appreciated
item.dc:creator: @x1_att_ftw_x x1 att ftw x
item.description:
@x1_att_ftw_x wrote:

if i do change2 = 100 - change;
the answer will be 98.14
i need the answer to be 86 because i already know that im going to need 1 dollar from 1.86
so how do i calculate the remainder of 1.86?
it would be change / 1 but java divides integer a different way. the answer isn’t 1.86 its 1 (In Java. 1.86 / 1 = 1, where it should be equal to 1.86.
if it is equal to 1.86 then i can subtract it by 1.00 and get .86 and obtain the modulus by .25 (.86 % .25) the problem is, i cant get the value to equal .86.

Read full topic

item.title: Need some help with Math, in Java. Help is appreciated
item.dc:creator: @x1_att_ftw_x x1 att ftw x
item.description:
@x1_att_ftw_x wrote:

import java.text.DecimalFormat;
public class MakingChange {

	/**
	 * @param args
	 */
	
	public static int loonies, toonies, quarters, dimes, nickles, pennies;
	public static double change = 1.86;
	public static double change2;
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		toonies = (int) (change / 2);
		loonies = (int) (change / 1);
		change2 = (int) change - 1.00;
		quarters = (int) (change2 / 25 % 25);
		dimes = (int) (change / 10 % 10);
		nickles = (int) (change / 5 % 5);
		pennies = (int) (change / 1 % 1);
		System.out.println(change2);
		System.out.println("Amount Of Change: " + change);
		System.out.println("Toonies:\t" + toonies);
		System.out.println("Loonies:\t" + loonies);
		System.out.println("Quarters:\t" + quarters);
		System.out.println("Dimes:\t\t" + dimes);
		System.out.println("Nickles:\t" + nickles);
		System.out.println("Pennies:\t" + pennies);
	}

}

im trying to get the value of change2 but java does integer division abit different and since its an integer it rounds to .86 to 0.0
I need to convert it into a double but when i do that it become 0.8600000000000001
Can i use the DecimalFormat Class?

Read full topic

item.title: Need some help with Math, in Java. Help is appreciated
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

How amusing. This is something I was assigned in Uni too.
It’s possible to create something decent with the use of arrays and then iterating through each coin denomination, finding the results and printing them out as you go. If you wanted to store the values for later use, you could use two arrays to keep hold of both.
Remember that good design is important.

item.title: Need some help with Math, in Java. Help is appreciated
item.dc:creator: @x1_att_ftw_x x1 att ftw x
item.description:
@x1_att_ftw_x wrote:

So i’m trying to figure out how to correctly initialize my variables for this program that my teacher assigned. The person who finishes it correctly get 2 bonus marks on their previous test so:

Firstly, the program is called MakingChange, it uses a variable to see how much Toonies, Loonies, Quarters, Nickles, Dimes, or pennies needed to make that specific Number
For example: If the amount it $1.86 then a println will display the following
Change: $1.86

Toonies: 0
Loonies: 1
Quarters: 3
Dimes: 1
Nickles: 0
Pennies: 1
i have to use the Division (/) and Modulus symbols (%) to store data.
This is what i have to far. please note that this is extremely beginner and that the simplistic way of calculating this is needed. There’s no need for if statements and such.

public class MakingChange {

	/**
	 * @param args
	 */
	public static int loonies, toonies, quarters, dimes, nickles, pennies;
	public static double change = 1.16;
	public static double change2;
	
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		toonies = (int) (change / 2);
		loonies = (int) (change / 1);
		quarters = (int) (change / loonies % .25);
		dimes = (int) (change / 10 % 17);
		nickles = (int) (change / 5 % 1);
		pennies = (int) (change / 1 % 185);
		
		System.out.println("Amount Of Change: " + change);
		System.out.println("Toonies:\t" + toonies);
		System.out.println("Loonies:\t" + loonies);
		System.out.println("Quarters:\t" + quarters);
		System.out.println("Dimes:\t\t" + dimes);
		System.out.println("Nickles:\t" + nickles);
		System.out.println("Pennies:\t" + pennies);
	}

}

Obviously if i change the value of the change then the end product will be different, i need it to calculate that correct change no matter what value is.

Read full topic
